Macenko, Paul
            Macenko, ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Macenko, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Paul, 70, of Caldwell, died Wednesday (March 14, 2001) at his residence.
            He ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> He >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 was born July 4, 1930, in Coal Ridge, son of the late Joseph and Mary Sabanos Macenko.
            He ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> He >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 was a veteran of the United States Army; a former employee of the former Edminston Lumber Mill at Caldwell; member of Corpus Christi Catholic Church in Belle Valley and Belle Valley Post 641 American Legion.
In addition to his parents, he was preceded in death by six brothers, Andy, Joe, John, Mike, George and Steve Macenko; two sisters, Margaret Mika and Mary Briggs.
            He ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> He >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 leaves four sisters-in-law, Anna of Lancaster, Nellie of Yorkville, Helen of Belle Valley and Luella Macenko of Caldwell; a brother-in-law, Gilbert Briggs of Lewisville; several nieces and nephews.
            Friends ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Friends >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 may call 6 to 8 p.m. today at McVay-Perkins Funeral Home in Caldwell. Mass of Christian burial will be celebrated Monday at 10 a.m. with Father Dale Tornes as celebrant. Burial will follow at Mount Calvary Cemetery in Belle Valley. Source: The Daily Jeffersonian, Cambridge, Ohio, March 2001

Maderia, Clarice M.
Source--Brooke Review    Brook County, Brook County, >>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 w:st="on">West Virginia
Published-- May 18, 2000
  Maderia, ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Maderia, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Clarice M., 81, of St. Clairsville, formerly of Follansbee, died Friday, May 12, 2000,
in Peterson Rehabilitation Hospital and Geriatric Center, Wheeling. She was a retired
registered nurse at Ohio Valley Hospital, Steubenville, and was a member of the Hooverson
Heights Church of Christ, Follansbee. She was preceded in death by her husband, John A.
Maderia; her parents, Frank J. and Clarabel Wells Pollack; an infant sister. Surviving are two
daughters, Cheryl Malone of Crofton, Maryland, Delia Ballog and her husband, Tom of Jerusalem,
Ohio; one brother, Frank J. Pollack of Elizabethtown, Pennsylvania; four grandchildren, Michael and
Rebecca Malone, Kristen Wallace, Sarah Ballog; three great-grandchildren.
  Arrangements ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Arrangements >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 by James Funeral Home, Follansbee. Interment in Independence Cemetery,
Independence, Pennsylvania, Follansbee. Memorial contributions may be made to Sunrise Acres
Ranch, in care of P.O. Box 376, Barnesville, Ohio 43713

Mahoney, Charles L.
Source--Monroe County Beacon     Woodsfield, ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Woodsfield, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Ohio
Published--Thursday, June 17, 2004
    Mahoney, ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Mahoney, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Charles L.,"Chuck", 76, of 44952 Moose Ridge Road, Woodsfield, died June 14,2004 at his home. He was born February 28, 1928, at Woodsfield, a son of the late Trella Scott Mahoney.
    He was a ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> He was a >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 self-employed contractor and was a Methodist by faith. He was a United States Army veteran and was also an avid hunter and fisherman.
    Surviving are ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Surviving are >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 his wife, Betty J. Stimpert, whom he married April 24, 1948; four daughters, Mrs. Robert (Peggy) Pierce, of Salesville, Mrs. Harold (Debra) Scott, of Woodsfield, Mrs. Rick (Brenda) Patterson, of Barnesville, Mrs. Charles (Evone "Kris") Delong, of Lewisville; three sons, John Mahoney and wife Kate, of Akron, Pat Mahoney, of the home, Neal Mahoney and wife, Lori, of Woodsfield; two sisters, Ila Sims, Lenora Bonadio, both of Woodsfield; 21 grandchildren; 29 great-grandchildren; special friend and partner, Luke Burke, of Woodsfield; several nieces and nephews.
    In addition ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> In addition >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 to his parents, he was preceded in death by three brothers, Joe Mahoney, Harold Ricer, and Clarence "Pete" Mahoney; three sisters, Maxine Sims, Maude Scott and Hazel Ault.
    Friends were ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Friends were >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 received at Watters Funeral Home, Woodsfield, June 15, where funeral services will be held June 16, at 1 p.m., with Reverend Roger Brown officiating. Burial will follow in Oaklawn Cemetery, Woodsfield with full military graveside services.
    Memorial contributions may be made to The American Cancer Society,  ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Memorial contributions may be made to The American Cancer Society, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 215 Marion Street

     Majors, ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'>
Majors, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Helen "Jean", 77, 305 North Main Street, Woodsfield, died October 16, 2004, at her home. She was born January 8, 1927, at Rockwood, Tennessee, a daughter of the late Henry Thomas and Maggie Lou Main Melhorn.
    She was a homemaker and a member of The First Baptist Church of Woodsfield.
    Surviving ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> She was a homemaker and a member of The First Baptist Church of Woodsfield.
Surviving >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 are three sons; Jennings B. (Jennifer) Majors, Jr. of Henderson, North Carolina, David Wayne Majors and Joseph Todd (Teri) Majors, all of Woodsfield; two sisters, Margaret Elizabeth Henderson, of Jasper, Tennessee, Dorothy Sue Armes of Oklahoma; two brothers, Carl Melhorn, of Dayton, Richard Melhorn, of Las Vegas: nine grandchildren; three great-grandchildren ;  several nieces and nephews.    
   In addition ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> several nieces and nephews.
In addition >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 to her parents, she was preceded in death by her husband, Jennings B. Majors, Sr., January 30, 2000.

Burial will follow in Oaklawn Cemetery, Woodsfield.
 
Mallett, Albert Bert
            Albert ======= JA'>Albert Bert
Albert >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 (Bert) Mallett, 87, of Lewisville, Route two, died Tuesday night, May 7, 1974, at 9:10 o'clock in Marietta Memorial Hospital following an <<<<<<< HEAD extended illness.                      He ======= extended illness. He >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 was born in Monroe County, March 29, 1887, a son of the late James and Harriett (McElfresh) Mallett. Mr. Mallett was a retired farmer, and a member of the United Methodist Church. surviving are two sons, James H. Mallett, of Mansfield, and Joseph W. Mallett, of Lewisville, Route two; two grandchildren; seven great-grandchildren; four sisters, Mrs. Margaret Gibson and Mrs. Mary Baker, of Lewisville; Mrs. Hazel Martin, of Sycamore Valley, and Mrs. Gladys Strickling, of Ravenna, and two brothers, Miles Mallett, of Canton, and William Mallett of Stafford.   His wife Edna (Dearth) Mallett, died in 1940. ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> His wife Edna (Dearth) Mallett, died in 1940. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Funeral services were held Friday afternoon at one o'clock in the Mallett Funeral Home at Stafford, with Reverend Thomas Clark officiating. Burial was in Sutherland Cemetery.
 
Mallett, Argel
            Argel ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Argel >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Mallett, 91, of Cornerstone Drive, Marietta, and a former resident of Lower Salem, died at 10:10 a.m. Friday (April 12, 2002) at Marietta Memorial Hospital. He was born November 25, 1910, near Stafford to Wales W. and Cora Crum Mallett.
            He ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> He >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 attended school at Stafford and graduated from Elk Rural High School at Hariettsville. He had worked at Wheeling Steel at Steubenville and was a dairy farmer. He had been president of Marietta Milk Producers Co-Op, was a member of Great Lakes Milk Board, Central Ohio Milk Producers, Southeastern Milk Producers Co-op, National Federation of Milk Producers, Washington County Health Department, Washington County Soil Conservation Service board, Salem-Liberty School board member, and attended the O'Neill Senior Citizens Center. He attended Faith Bible Church. He taught Sunday school for 50 years and was an avid Bible student and scholar.
            On ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> On >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 May 13, 1933, he married Esther L. Stephens who survives with one daughter, Betty A. Haas of Marietta; one grandchild, Lee Haas; and six great-grandchildren. Also surviving are three brothers, Riley Mallett of Dunedin, Florida, Hubert Mallett of Mingo Junction and Ivan Mallett of Vero Beach, Florida; and two sisters, Gladys Bergman of Columbus and Violet Pierce of Steubenville.
            He ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> He >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 was preceded in death by his parents; one son, James Richard Mallett; one brother, Clayton Mallett; one sister, Bernice Nichols Gilreath; and one grandson, Rex Haas.
            Services ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Services >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 are at 10:30 a.m. Monday at McClure-Schafer-Lankford Funeral Home in Marietta with Pastor Raymond Witmer III officiating. Burial is in Salem Township Cemetery. Friends may call from 2 p.m. Sunday at the funeral home. The family will greet friends from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 p.m. Sunday at the funeral home.
Source: The Marietta Times, Marietta, Ohio, April 13, 2002

She was born in Woodsfield, March 24, 1919, a daughter of the late Homer L. and Marie Christman Hamilton.

She was also a member of the Veterans of Foreign Wars Ladies Auxiliary Post 5108, where she had served as a past president and was also a member of the Franklin Homemakers Club at Lewisville.

Hamilton, of Columbus; three grandchildren, Doug, Mike, and Christy Burton, of Canal Winchester; several nieces and nephews.

Mallett, on August 6, 1994, whom she married January 12, 1947; two sisters, Hilda Smith, Opal Schwall; three brothers, Edwin Hamilton, Willard Hamilton and Ray Hamilton.

Source: The Monroe County Beacon, dated Thursday, January 1, 2004
 
Mallett, Eunice M. (nee Ullman)

She was born February 12, 1911, a daughter of the late R. Herbert and Mary (McConnell) Ullman. A former resident of Mansfield, she had spent the last 16 years in Lakeland.
            She ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> She >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 was a retired secretary. She was a member of the American Legion Auxiliary Post No 16, Mansfield; the First United Methodist Church, Lakeland, and the Homebuilders Sunday School Class. She is survived by her husband, James H. Mallett, Lakeland; daughter, Martha Rose Mossbarger, Lakeland; sister, Irene Hogue; Lewisville, Ohio; brother, Raymond H. Ullman, Jr., Marietta; three grandchildren, and one great grandchild.
            Funeral ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Funeral >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 services were held December 12, at the Gentry-Morrison Funeral Home Chapel. Burial was in the Oak Hill Burial Park, Lakeland.

Mallett, Gladys (nee Ullman)

She was born September 30, 1909, at Stafford, a daughter of the late Henry and Caroline (Schwartz) Ullman.
            She ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> She >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 attended the First Christian Church,Beallsville, Ohio. She is survived by a son, Roy,Beallsville, Ohio; one grandson, Dan Mallett,Beallsville, Ohio, two granddaughters, Mrs. Jack (Peggy) Douglas and Mrs. Brad (Patty) McGlumphy, both of Barnesville; five great-grandchildren. Mallett, James H.
            >>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 w:st="on">Lakeland, Florida-James H. Mallett of Lakeland died Thursday (August 19, 1993) at Lakeland Regional Medical Center. He was 81. Born in Stafford, Ohio, on March 2, 1912, he came to Lakeland from Mansfield, Ohio, more than 20 years ago. He was a licensed funeral director for more than 60 years and worked 20 years with Gentry-Morrison Funeral Home.
            He ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> He >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 was an Army veteran of World War II and a member of the American Legion Post 16 of Mansfield. He was a member of the 40 and 8 club and the Voyager 20 Club. He was a member of the First United Methodist Church of Lakeland. He was proceeded in death by his wife Eunice (Ullman) Mallett, in 1990. He is survived by his daughter, Martha Mossbarger, Lakeland; a brother, Joseph Mallett, Stafford, Ohio; three grandchildren, and one great-grandchild. Services will be at 10:30 this morning at the Gentry-Morrison Funeral Home, Southside Chapel, 1727 Bartow Road, Lakeland
 
Mallett, Joan and Ivan Winland
            On Saturday afternoon, October 21, 1950 at two oclock in the Hartshorn Ridge Church of Christ, Miss Joan Mallett, ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> On Saturday afternoon, October 21, 1950 at two o clock in the Hartshorn Ridge Church of Christ, Miss Joan Mallett, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Mallett, of Lewisville, Ohio, Route two, became the bride of Ivan Winland, son of Mrs. Martha Rose Cline, of New Matamoras, Ohio, Route two.
            Minister J. V. A. Traylor read the double ring ceremony before a large gathering of friends and relatives. Preceding the ceremony Minister Traylor sang I Love You Truly and At Dawning.
            Given in marriage by her father, the ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Minister J. V. A. Traylor read the double ring ceremony before a large gathering of friends and relatives. Preceding the ceremony Minister Traylor sang I Love You Truly and At Dawning.
Given in marriage by her father, the >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 bride was lovely in a white satin gown fashioned with a pointed bodice and long fitted sleeves, which tapered to points over the hands. She carried a white Bible topped with a white orchid from which fell satin streamers. The tradition of something old, something new, something borrowed, something blue and a penny in her shoe was carried out.
            Mrs. John Stimpert, of Mrs. John Stimpert, of >>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 w:st="on">Columbus was matron of honor. Miss Rosie Hartshorn, aunt of the bride was bridesmaid.
            Phillip Hartshorn, little cousin of ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Phillip Hartshorn, little cousin of >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 the bride, was ring bearer. Jimmy Hines, close friend of the groom served as best man. Ushers were Forrest Graham, of Norwich, cousin of the groom, and John Dougherty, of Woodsfield.
            For her daughters wedding Mrs. ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> For her daughter s wedding Mrs. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Mallett wore a fall green suit with black accessories. Mrs. Cline mother of the bridegroom also wore a fall green suit and wore brown accessories. Both wore corsages of yellow roses.
            Mrs. Ray Hartshorn, grandmother of ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Mrs. Ray Hartshorn, grandmother of >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 the bride, wore a grey dress with black accessories. Mrs. Forrest Dye, maternal grandmother of the groom, was attired in a taupe brown dress with black accessories, and Mrs. William Winland, paternal grandmother of the groom wore a black dress with black accessories.
            Present for her great granddaughters wedding was Mrs. Harriet Mallett. She wore a grey suit with ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Present for her great granddaughter s wedding was Mrs. Harriet Mallett. She wore a grey suit with >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 black accessories and a corsage of white carnations.
            Immediately following the ceremony a reception for 125 guests was held at the home of the brides parents. Centering the brides table was a four-tiered wedding cake topped with a miniature bride ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Immediately following the ceremony a reception for 125 guests was held at the home of the bride s parents. Centering the bride s table was a four-tiered wedding cake topped with a miniature bride >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 and groom.
            Hostess for the reception were Miss ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Hostess for the reception were Miss >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Jean Baker of Croton; Miss Irma Highman of Woodsfield; Miss Carrie Ann Hines, of Lewisville; Mrs. Sam Hartshorn of Canton, Ohio; and Mrs. Demoin Hartshorn, of Graysville.
            For her wedding trip, the new Mrs. ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> For her wedding trip, the new Mrs. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Winland chose a suit of taupe brown with green and brown accessories. Her corsage was a white orchid.
            After a weeks trip to After a week s trip to >>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 w:st="on">Washington, D. C. and Florida, the newlyweds returned to their newly furnished home at Rinard Mills.
            Mrs. Winland is a graduate of ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Mrs. Winland is a graduate of >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Stafford high school, Stafford, Ohio, while Mr. Winland is a graduate of Graysville high school, Graysville, Ohio.
Source: The Monroe County Beacon, Woodsfield, Ohio, November 23, 1950
 
Mallett, Joseph W.
            Pickerington, ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Pickerington, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Ohio - Joseph W. Mallett, 89, of Pickerington, formerly of Sand Bar Road, Lewisville, died Tuesday (February 25, 2003) at Fairfield Medical Center in Lancaster. He was born December 10, 1913, in Monroe County to Albert "Bert" and Edna Dearth Mallett. He was a retired farmer and construction worker.
            He is survived by his wife, Ruth ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> He is survived by his wife, Ruth >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Hartshorn Mallett; one daughter, Joan Winland and her husband, Ivan, of Pickerington; three granddaughters, Pamela Karnes and her husband, Craig, Aleisa Lee and her husband, Gregary, and Susan Campbell and her husband, Robert, all of Pickerington; one grandson, Timothy Winland and his wife, Lisa, of Hilliard; and eight great-grandchildren, Danielle and Bradley Karnes, Mathew, Cody and Hunter Lee, Parker and Madison Campbell and Nicholas Winland.
             He was preceded in death by three infant sons; his parents; and one brother, James Mallett.
             Services are at 2 p.m. Saturday at ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> He was preceded in death by three infant sons; his parents; and one brother, James Mallett.
Services are at 2 p.m. Saturday at >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Bauer-Turner Funeral Home, 100 South Paul Street, Woodsfield, with Minister Tim Fleeman officiating. Burial is in Hartshorn Ridge Cemetery near Graysville. Friends will be received from noon until the hour of the service at the funeral home. Memorial contributions may be made to the Hartshorn Ridge Cemetery or the Sutherland Cemetery.
Source: The Marietta Times, Thursday, February, 29, 2003

Mallett, Ralph W.
            Ralph W. Mallett , 77, of Ralph W. Mallett , 77, of >>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 w:st="on">44938 State Route 145, Lewisville, died at 5:35 p.m. Saturday, August 6, 1994, at his home. He was born near Lewisville on December 8, 1916 a son of the late Clem and Mae Brown Mallet. Mr. Mallet was a farmer and retired electrician. He was a lifetime member of The Sutherland United Methodist Church near Stafford, a United States Army Veteran of World War II, lifetime member of The Veterans of foreigh War Post 5108, Marietta and The Military Order of Cooties Post 63, Marietta. He was also a retired member of I.B.E.W. Local 968, Marietta and a member of Stafford Lodge No.300 F.and A.M., Stafford.
            Surviving are his wife, Elsie Hamilton ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Surviving are his wife, Elsie Hamilton >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Mallett, whom he married on January 12, 1947; two daughters, Kathy Mallett of Marietta and Mrs. Richard (Vicki) Burton of Canal Winchester; two sisters, Mrs. Robert (Martha) Warden of Marietta and Mrs. Peter (Dorothy) Ciesielczyk of Canton; two brothers, Albert Mallett of Lewisville and Bernard Mallett of Anaheim, California; three grandchildren, Douglas, Michael and Christy Burton and 13 nieces and nephews. In addition to his parents, he was preceded in death by a brother, Edmond Mallett.
            Friends were received at the Watters ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Friends were received at the Watters >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Funeral Home, 37501 State Route 78 West, Woodsfield, where services were held at 11 a.m. August 10, with Reverend Kevin Rinkes officiating. Burial followed in The Sutherland Cemetery near Stafford with full military graveside services conducted by the Veterans of foreign War Post 5108, Marietta. Memorial contributions may be made to Woodsfield Hospice, 797 Lewisville Road, Woodsfield. Source: The Monroe County Beacon, Woodsfield,Ohio, August 1994.

Mann, Catherine (nee Claus)
            Mrs. Catherine Claus Mann, aged 66, ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Mrs. Catherine Claus Mann, aged 66, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 widow of George Mann died of a hart attack at her home in Jerusalem Tuesday morning at 11:30, January 23, 1951. She had been in her usual good health and her death came as a shock to her family and friends.
            She was born near Miltonsburg, Ohio on February 20, 1884 a daughter of Adolph and Elizabeth Fliehman Claus. In her youth she was confirmed in Saint Peters Evangelical and Reformed Church at ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> She was born near Miltonsburg, Ohio on February 20, 1884 a daughter of Adolph and Elizabeth Fliehman Claus. In her youth she was confirmed in Saint Peter s Evangelical and Reformed Church at >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Miltonsburg but later in life transferred her membership to the Presbyterian Church in Jerusalem, Ohio.
            On December 19, 1903 she was united ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> On December 19, 1903 she was united >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 in marriage to George Mann and they spent their married life in the Jerusalem community. Mr. Mann passed away on February 2, 1945.
            Mrs. Mann is survived by two ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Mrs. Mann is survived by two >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 daughters, Mrs. Viola Riley of Beallsville, Ohio and Mrs. Lawson (Bernice) Gibbons of Massillon; two sons Ronald of Canton, Ohio; Royden of Smithfield, Ohio; 10 grandchildren; one sister, Mrs. Charles (Lucetta) Mann of Miltonsburg and three brothers, William and John of Woodsfield and Oscar of near Jerusalem.
            Funeral services will be held this Thursday afternoon at 2:00 oclock in the Jerusalem Presbyterian Church with ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Funeral services will be held this Thursday afternoon at 2:00 o clock in the Jerusalem Presbyterian Church with >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 the Reverend Byron Evans of the Barnesville Presbyterian Church officiating. Interment will be made in the Jerusalem cemetery by the Blowers-Campbell funeral home of Beallsville, Ohio, where friends are being received. Source: The Monroe County Beacon, Woodsfield, Ohio, January 1951.

Mr. Mann is a Monroe County boy who has made good being a graduate of The Ohio State University and leaves a paying position at Youngstown, Ohio, to go to the service of his country.

Mann, Elisha A.
            Saturday of last week Elisha Mann, ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Saturday of last week Elisha Mann, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 son of Mr. and Mrs. M. M. Mann, was fatally injured while working at an oil well near Wooster, Ohio, by being struck just below the stomach with a heavy plank.
            The news of the accident was recieved ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> The news of the accident was recieved >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 here Sunday and Mr. Mann left at once for Wooster and on Monday, Mrs. Mann went also hoping that something might be done to save their son's life but all was in vain. The injury was to great and the unfortunate man died Monday evening. The remains were brought to Woodsfield Tuesday. The time for the funeral has not been fixed.
             Deceased was 23 years of age and unmarried. He ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Deceased was 23 years of age and unmarried. He >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 was an industrious young man and had many friends. The grief stricken parents and brothers and sisters have the profound sympathy of many friends here and in other parts of the country where the family is well known.
Source: The Spirit of Democracy, Thursday, September 27, 1917

Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. G. Smith, of Lewisville, Ohio Route 1, Saturday evening September seventeenth, nineteen hundred and forty nine.

            For her wedding the bride chose a ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> For her wedding the bride chose a >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 blonde two-piece dress of slipper satin with navy blue accessories. Her only jewelry was a pearl necklace and watch, both gifts of the groom. The tradition of something old, something blue, and a penny in her shoe, was carried out. Her corsage was a white gardenia with small red rosebuds.
            The bride, a graduate of Somerton ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> The bride, a graduate of Somerton >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 high school, has been employed at the Barnesville General hospital, Barnesville, Ohio.

             Preceding the ceremony a program of nuptial ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Preceding the ceremony a program of nuptial >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 music was presented by Mrs. Allen Mann, organist, sister-in-law of the bride. Gallagher at the home of the bride's sister and brother-in-law, Mr. and Mrs. Carl VanFossen, before an improvised altar of beautiful baskets of summer flowers.

The fitted bodice was designed with bateau neckline and long sheer fitted sleeves. Her veil of silk illusion was held in place by a pearl and crystal crown adorned with pearlized orange blossoms. She carried a colonial bouquet of white carnations.

She was attired in a white suit with red accessories and carried a colonial bouquet of red carnations.

Mann, Lyman J.
            Another aged and lifelong citizen of Monroe has passed to the great beyond in the person of Lyman J. Mann, who died at his home on West Marietta street, Saturday evening, March 25, 1922, at 6:00 oclock after a long illness from Brights disease.
            Mr. ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Another aged and lifelong citizen of Monroe has passed to the great beyond in the person of Lyman J. Mann, who died at his home on West Marietta street, Saturday evening, March 25, 1922, at 6:00 o clock after a long illness from Bright s disease.
Mr. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Mann was born in Malaga township, Monroe County, Ohio on the 4th of December, 1845, and was 76 years, 3 months and 21 days old, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hughes Mann. In the year, 1880, he was united in marriage with Mrs. Henrietta Stenzel of Miltonsburg. A family of three children were born to this union.
            He leaves an aged wife, son Paul Mann of Woodsfield and one daughter, Mrs. Ward Vospe of Columbus; (one daughter Mrs. Leo ORourke preceded him in death); two stepdaughters, Mrs. Theodore Menkel of He leaves an aged wife, son Paul Mann of Woodsfield and one daughter, Mrs. Ward Vospe of Columbus; (one daughter Mrs. Leo O Rourke preceded him in death); two stepdaughters, Mrs. Theodore Menkel of >>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 w:st="on">Ansonia, Ohio, and Mrs. James Wharton of Jackson Ridge. Also two sisters, Mrs. Theodore Thornberry of Steubenville and Mrs. Loretta Johnston of Woodsfield, eight grandchildren and a large circle of other relatives and friends survive.
            The ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> The >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 funeral took place at the home last Monday afternoon, with Reverend George L. Davis of the M. E. church in charge, and his remains were laid to rest in Oaklawn cemetery.
            The funeral was attended by a large number of relatives and friends including the following from a distance: Mrs. M. A. Eberle of Cambridge; L. D. ORourke and ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> The funeral was attended by a large number of relatives and friends including the following from a distance: Mrs. M. A. Eberle of Cambridge; L. D. O Rourke and >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 three daughters, Carrie, Norma and Thelma of East Pittsburg, Pennsylvania; Dean Gramlich of Barnesville; Mr. and Mrs. Theo. Thornberry and Mrs. C. H. Rine of Steubenville; Mrs. T. F. Menkle of Ansonia, Ohio; Mr. and Mrs. Ward Vosper and son of Columbus; Misses Ella and Louise Watson of Quaker City; Miss Emma Gramlich of Bridgeport, and Miss Matilda Wharton of Bellaire.
            The floral offerings were many and very fine. Mr. Mann was a member of one of Monroe Countys ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> The floral offerings were many and very fine. Mr. Mann was a member of one of Monroe County s >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 most highly respected pioneer families, had many friends wherever known, and had spent his entire life in this County.
            The ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> The >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 widow and family have the sincere sympathy of many friends. His memory will long be cherished by those who knew him for the kind and loving character he was. Source: The Spirit of Democracy, March 30 and April 6, 1922

Mann, Okey

            Okey ======= JA'> Okey >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 D. Mann, 81, of 414 High Street, Woodsfield, retired Monroe County Highway Department employee, died unexpectedly early Monday afternoon, August 7th, at his home. He was mowing his lawn when stricken.

            Born ======= JA'> Born >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 in Monroe County, May 29, 1891, he was a son of Henry and Susan Barber Mann.

             Surviving are one daughter, Mrs. R. W. (Vera) ======= JA'> Surviving are one daughter, Mrs. R. W. (Vera) >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Egger of Woodsfield; two sons, William Mann of Woodsfield, and James Mann of Wichita, Kansas; one granddaughter, Mrs. Gary (Nancy) Rubel of Summerfield Route 1; two great grandsons and one sister, Mrs. Everett Okey of Fort Worth, Texas.

            His ======= JA'> His >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 wife, Willa Moore Mann, died in 1968, and a son, Robert Mann died in 1965.

Egger, Vera, nee Mann
Barnesville Enterprise, May 15, 2002
Egger, Vera M. : Services were held Saturday at Watters Funeral Home, Woodsfield, for Vera M. Egger, 88, of High Street Woodsfield, who died Wednesday May 8, 2002 at the Monroe County Care Center in Woodsfield. Pastor Donald Rock will officiate. Burial will be in the Oaklawn Cemetery, Woodsfield. Friends were received Friday at the funeral home. She was born May 3, 1914, in Woodsfield, daughter of the late David Okey and Willa (Moore) Mann. Mrs. Egger was a homemaker and had formerly worked with her husband at the former L.P. Egger and Son Hardware Store in Woodsfield. She was a member of the St. Paul's United Church of Christ in Woodsfield, where she was a member of the Junior Women's Guild. She was a former member of Pythian Sisters in Woodsfield. She was preceded in death by her husband, Raymond Egger, who died Oct. 25, 1971; and three brothers, Robert Mann, William Mann, and James Mann. She leaves a daughter, Mrs. Gary (Nancy) Rubel of Woodsfield; two grandchildren. Randy (Glenda) Rubel and Jeff (Cheryl) Rubel, both of Lewisville; five great-grandchildren, Sheri, Melissa, Diana, Joshua and Brandon Rubel; and two nieces and nephews. Memorial contributions may be made to St. Paul's United Church of Christ, 303 South Main St. Woodsfield, OH 43793 or to the Monroe County Care Center, 47025 Moore Ridge Rd. Woodsfield Oh 43793.
 
 
Mann, Vernon Howard

Markey, Courtney

August 16, 1989

IN PAGEANT

Courtney Markey

Source: Monroe County Beacon

     Courtney Nicole Markey, six, ======= JA'> Courtney Nicole Markey, six, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 daughter of Ron and Tammy of Lewisville participated in the Miss American Princess Pageant held in Columbus. Every girl received a State Finalist trophy. Courtney earned an embroidered banner, crown trophy and cash as well. She was also recognized for her outstanding program participation as hostess third runner up.

     Courtney would like to thank ======= JA'> Courtney would like to thank >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 those people and business that supported her. Fleeman Insurance; Pat's Gift Shoppe, Watters Funeral Homes, Knowlton Ford-Mercury, Inc; Gallagher and Sons Monuments; Webers Pharmacy; Bellwood Drugs; J and M Auto Sales/Rental; Bauer-Turner and David C. Baker D.C., Inc

Marple, Jonathan
             Jonathan Marple died at his home near Jonathan Marple died at his home near >>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 w:st="on">Griffith, Ohio, July 1, 1897. Born Virginia 9 October 1824, moved with parents to West Virginia 1836. Married Susan Blair September 16, 1849. Seven children - four girls, three boys, of which two girls and two boys are living. United with Presbyterian Church in 1853. Came to Ohio 1880, settling in Monroe County and united with M.P. Church in 1881. Funeral services held in M.E. Church, Jackson Ridge, conducted by Reverend R.D. Wilson of Lewisville. Source: The Monroe Gazette, July 8, 1897.

Marshall, E. E. and Miss Lucy Lynch
            Wednesday of last week, October 17, ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Wednesday of last week, October 17, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 1917, at one o'clock, was solemnized the marriage of Mr. E. E. Marshall and Miss Lucy Lynch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E.L. Lynch. The ceremony was performed by Reverend A. H. Knipping, pastor of St. Paul's Evangelical Church at the home of the bride on Paul Street. The attendants were Mr. Carl Reinherr and Miss Ida Hall and Miss Kathryn Beardmore. The happy couple left immediately after the ceremony for a few days honeymoon. They will make their home in Woodsfield among their many friends who unite in wishing them a long and happy married life.
Source: The Spirit of Democracy, Thursday, October 25, 1917.
 
Marshall, Floyd E.
Source--Wetzel Chronical       West ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> West >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Virginia
Published--October 16, 2002
Marshall, Floyd E., 75, of Pine Grove, West Virginia., died Friday,
October 11, 2002 at his home. He was a member of the Lowman Baptist Church near Pine Grove. He retired from Ormet Corporation, Hannibal, Ohio with 25 years service and he was an Army veteran. He was preceded in death by his first wife, Anna Grace Barr Marshall; his parents, Raymond and Della Stoneking Marshall; one grandson, Travis Haught; and two brothers, Raymond Patterson and Kenneth Marshall
Surviving are: his wife, Kathryn Barr Marshall; four daughters, Carol Haught, JoAnn Yoho, Judy Bickerstaff and Cherri Hayes, all of Pine Grove; one brother, John Carroll of Brewster, Ohio; two sisters, Doris Halstead of Delta, Pennsylvania, and Anna Mae Loy of Brewster, Ohio; fivegrandchildren, Nathaniel Yoho, Betsy Bickerstaff, DustinBickerstaff, Tamara Hayes and Tiffany Hayes; and one great.
Grandson, Dylan Yoho.
Friends were received 2-9 p.m. at Palmers Funeral ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'>Friend s were received 2-9 p.m. at Palmer s Funeral >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Home,
where services :were held Monday at 2 p.m. Interment at the Lowman Baptist near Pine Grove.

Martin, Alvilda J.
Source--Wetzel  Democrat         New Source--Wetzel Democrat New >>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 w:st="on">Martinsville, West Virginia
Published--February 22, 1918
 
======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
Martin, Alvilda J., widow of the late I. N. Martin, died Saturday, February 15, 1918, at her home in Smithfield, West Virginia., aged 67 years. The funeral srvices were held from her late home. Reverend. Hall officiated and her remains were taken to Enterprise, West Virginia., where interment was made. The deceased is survived by the following children: Mrs. Cora George of Shirley, West Virginia.; L. B. Martin of Woodsfield, Ohio; W. H. Martin of Smithfield; Mrs. H. L. McLaughlin of Junction City, Ohio; and Mrs. Hattie McMichael of Smithfield. Mrs. Martin was a highly esteemed lady.
SOURCE: "Wetzel Democrat", New Martinsville, West Virginia., February 22, 1918.

Martin, Charlotte (nee Crawford)
            Mrs. Charlotte Crawford Martin, widow ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Mrs. Charlotte Crawford Martin, widow >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 of Dr. John Martin and mother of Frank M. Martin, of The Republican, died at her home in Caldwell on Thursday last, September 5, in her 89th year.
            Mrs. Martin was the daughter of Judge ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Mrs. Martin was the daughter of Judge >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 and Mrs. David Kirkbride, citizens of Woodsfield in its early history, and was born December 22, 1829, in the home which stood on the lot where The Spriggs Building, occupied by The Spirit of Democracy now stands. She was the youngest and the last of 11 children of The Kirkbride Family to pass to the beyond.
            Mrs. Martin received her education in ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Mrs. Martin received her education in >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 the schools of those early days, attending the old Woodsfield Academy which stood on the site of the present grade school building in Woodsfield. After finishing the course at this institution she taught school for several terms.
            On August 3, 1854, she was united in ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> On August 3, 1854, she was united in >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 marriage with Dr. John Martin, also a native of Monroe County, who was born and raised in Bethel Township. To this union were born four sons; Walter C. of Cleveland, Frank M. of Woodsfield, Willis K., who died in infancy,in
1868 and Carl O. of Bainbridge, Ohio. Miss Ida Smith of Woodsfield is a niece.
            She is also survived by eight grandsons, one great granddaughter and one great grandsson.
            About three years after her marriage, ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> She is also survived by eight grandsons, one great granddaughter and one great grandsson.
About three years after her marriage, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 she, with her husband, removed to Monmouth, Illinois, where they lived for about five years, returning to Woodsfield in 1862. In 1864 they removed to Caldwell where she has lived in thiss house they bought before moving.
            Although never rugged in health and in ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Although never rugged in health and in >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 spite of her advanced years she retained her mental faculties until within a few short hours of her, when she fell into a sleep and passed peacefully and without a struggle into "that sleep which knows no waking," in this world. Mrs. Martin had always been a great reader until failing eyesight prevented. She then had someone read to her. She kept well informed on current events, and was deeply interested in the war news and was greatly rejoiced when victory came to the Allies, and especially so when American success and valor was mentioned. Only the day before her she asked to hear the news.
            The funeral was held Saturday ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> The funeral was held Saturday >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 afternoon at one o'clock. The services were conducted by Reverend Miller, pastor of The Baptist Church of Caldwell, of which she was a member.In early life she was a member of The Christian Church of Woodsfield, and has ever since been a member of some church. Interment in the family lot in The Olive Cemetery at Caldwell.
Source:The Spirit of Democracy, Woodsfield, Ohio, September 12, 1918
 
Martin , Christina Marie
Source--Wetzel Message Board       West Virginia
Published--August  ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> West Virginia
Published--August >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 1995
MARTIN, Christina Marie, 9, of Township Highway 403, Clarington, Ohio, died Thursday, August 10, 1995 as the result of an automobile accident near Woodsfield, Ohio. She was preceded in death by her father, Bruce Martin. Surviving are her mother, Tina Sidorak Martin of Bellaire, Ohio; two brothers, Steve and Darrell Martin of Cadiz; her foster parents, Reverend Jerry and Sherry Davis Boron of Clarington; two foster brothers, Jeremy and Michael Boron of Clarington, Ohio; a foster sister, Shana Boron of Clarington; paternal foster grandparents, Calvin and Mary Lee Smith Boron of New Matamoras; maternal foster grandparent, Hobert and Louise Wilson Davis of New Martinsville. Friends received at Wells Funeral Home, New Martinsville. Services was held at the New Martinsville Church of the Nazarene with Interment in Greenlawn Memorial Park, New Martinsville, Wetzel County, West Virginia.

Martin, Elizabeth Deem
Source--Ritchie Gazette       West ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> West >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Virginia
Published--March 16, 1989
"Ritchie Gazette" 16 March 1989 page 7
Deem, Mrs. Elizabeth "Libby" , 76, of Rt. 1, Harrisville, West Virginia, died Friday, March 10, 1989, in Camden-Clark Memorial Hospital, Parkersburg, West Virginia.
She was born in Ritchie County, West Virginia, a daughter of the late William H. and Abbie HAMRIC MARTIN. She was a homemaker and had attended Morris Chapel Evangelical United Brethern Church.
Surviving are her husband, Kenneth O. DEEM, Sr.; three sons, Kenneth O. DEEM, Jr., Doyle DEEM and Clifford DEEM, all of Route 1, Harrisville; two daughters, Dorothy GUMP of New Matamoras, Ohio, and Patricia "Patty" NUTTER of Harrisville; two brothers, Henry MARTIN of Masontown, West Virginia, and Burley MARTIN of Harrisville; 16 grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren.
Preceding her in death were two infant children, three brothers and three sisters.
Services were held at the Raiguel Funeral Home, Harrisville, with Evangelist Okey Lamp, officiating. Burial was in the Harrisville IOOF Cemetery.

He re-moved to his late home near Clarington, Ohio in 1901. He was graduated in medicine from The Old College of Medicine in Surgery at Cincinnati,Ohio in 1867.

Martin, Frank A. and Joanne Nalley
            Miss Joanne Nalley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mervin C. Nalley of Woodsfield, became the bride of Mr. Frank A. Martin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Earl Martin of Woodsfield in an open Church ceremony read at 2:30 oclock, Sunday afternoon October sixteenth in the Miss Joanne Nalley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mervin C. Nalley of Woodsfield, became the bride of Mr. Frank A. Martin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Earl Martin of Woodsfield in an open Church ceremony read at 2:30 o clock, Sunday afternoon October sixteenth in the >>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 w:st="on">First Methodist Church at Woodsfield. Reverend William M. Miller read the double ring ceremony.
            Preceding the wedding, nuptial music was presented by Miss Minnie Louise Decker, organist, and Mr. Dale Latimer, vocalist. The Lords Prayer was sung while the bride and groom were kneeling at ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Preceding the wedding, nuptial music was presented by Miss Minnie Louise Decker, organist, and Mr. Dale Latimer, vocalist. The Lords Prayer was sung while the bride and groom were kneeling at >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 the altar.
            The bride who was given in marriage ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> The bride who was given in marriage >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 by her father, wore a white brocaded taffeta gown of princess style. Her only jewelry was a strand of pearls, a gift of the groom. She carried out the tradition of something old, something new, something borrowed and something blue. Miss Jane Ludwig was maid of honor.
            Bridesmaids were Miss Dama Martin, ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Bridesmaids were Miss Dama Martin, >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 sister of the groom, and Miss Joanne Walter. Little Sharon Ann Herring, cousin of the bride, served as flower girl.
            Mr. Lucien Weber, brother of the ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Mr. Lucien Weber, brother of the >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 groom, served as best man. Ushers wee Messrs., Dan Feasel, Allen Feasel, Harlan Billman and Jack Christman.
            Mrs. Nalley, mother of the bride ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Mrs. Nalley, mother of the bride >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 wore a wine-colored dress with brown accessories while Mrs. Martin, mother of the groom, wore hunter green and matching accessories.
            A reception was held in the Church ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> A reception was held in the Church >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 parlor immediately following the ceremony. Senior hostess was Mrs. Harry Nowell, and assistant hostesses were Miss Violet Anderson, Mrs. Clark Cronin, Miss Leah Jean Swartzlander, and Miss Sally McCormick.
            When the newlyweds left for a short ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> When the newlyweds left for a short >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 wedding trip, the bride was attired in a brown gabardine suit with green accessories.

Sept. 22,
Laura E. McCarty , nee Martin
LEWISVILLE - Laura E. McCarty, 42, of 45994 Ohio 145, Lewisville, died Friday (Sept. 20, 2002) at Wheeling Hospital in Wheeling, W.Va.
She was born July 28, 1950, in Ferndale, Ky., to Charles and Kathryn Williams Martin. She was the operator of Hillcrest Manor in Lewisville for 22 years and was a board member of the M.R.D.D. in Monroe County for 10 years.
She is survived by her husband, Robert McCarty; one son, Larry Tidd Jr. of Delphos, Ohio; her mother of Lima; one brother, Leon Martin of Lima; four sisters, Julie Martin of South Carolina, Char Jenkins of Bluffton, Ohio, Connie Binkley of Lima and Ida Amstutz of Lima; and several nieces and nephews.
She was preceded in death by her father and one sister, Mary Martin.
Friends will be received from 3 to 6 p.m. today at Watters Funeral Home in Woodsfield. Burial will be held at the convenience of the family.
Memorial contributions may be made to Shiffler Cancer Center, in care of Wheeling Hospital, 1 Medical Center, Wheeling, W.Va. 26003.

Death was due to the infirmities of age being in his 87th year. Deceased was born in Monroe County, where he resided all his life.

She was born October. 20, 1914, near Marr, Monroe County, a daughter of the late Charlie and Mae Parks Bower. She had attended Indian Run School, which was on the family farm, and was a member of the Creighton Ridge Church of Christ. She enjoyed sewing and gardening.

In addition to her parents, she was preceded in death by her sister, Emma Kehl.

Marlin, Robert W. "Bob"
Source--Times Leader    ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'>Source--Times Leader >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Martins Ferry, Ohio
Published--October 29, 2004
Marlin, Robert W. "Bob" , 62, of Neffs, died Thursday, October 28, 2004, in the Belmont Community Hospital. He was born February 14, 1942, in Bellaire, a son of the late Frank (Jiggs) and Sarah Hall Marlin. Bob was a miner with Powhatan #3 mine and most recently employed at Loy's Building Center, Saint Clairsville, and was a Methodist by faith. In addition to his parents, Bob was preceded in death by a brother, George Marlin. Surviving are his wife, Anora Pitts Marlin; eight children, Robert Tharp of Louisiana, Timothy Tharp of Bellaire, Charles Garloch, and his wife, Lydia, of Neffs, Larry Garloch of Bellaire, and Donna Gress, Sherri Garloch Marlin, Lisa Cole, and Bobbi Jo Porter, and her husband, Scott, all of Neffs; three brothers, Mike and William Marlin of Bellaire and Jeff Marlin, and his wife, Margie, of Parkersburg, West Virginia.; three sisters, all of Bellaire, Mary Lish, and her husband, Jim, Gerry Heath, and her husband, Bill, and Debra Palmer; 15 grandchildren and one great-grandson, Robert Matt Orosz of Neffs. Friends will be received on Friday, October 29, from 2 to 4 p.m. and 6 to 8 p.m. at the Bauknecht-Altmeyer Funeral Homes and Crematory, 441 37th Street, Bellaire, where services will be held on Saturday at 1 p.m., with Pastor David Demarest officiating. Burial will follow in Linwood Cemetery, Blaine. Memorial contributions may be made to the Neffs Fire Department, Box 227, Neffs. ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
Marty, Mr. John Wesley and Miss Alma Louise Moser
               A pretty little wedding took ======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> A pretty little wedding took >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 place last Wednesday morning at the home of Mr. and Mrs. H. J. Feldner. Miss Alma Louise Moser of Hannibal, Ohio, a relative of Mrs. Feldner, and Mr. John Wesley Marty, also of Hannibal, Ohio were the principals. The marriage was solemnized by the Reverend E. Seybold. The beautiful ring service was used. May it truly be a symbol of endless love. After the service the bridal party partook of a sumptuous dinner prepared by Mrs. Feldner in honor of the occasion. The best wishes of many friends accompany Mr. and Mrs. Marty on their journey through life.
Source:The Spirit of Democracy, Woodsfield, Ohio, Thursday, May 4, 1916.
 
Marty, Lillian E. , nee Fraley
Source--Monroe County Beacon   Woodsfield, Ohio
Published--Thursday  December 23, 2004
            illian ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Woodsfield, Ohio
Published--Thursday December 23, 2004
illian >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 E. Fraley Marty, 95, of Clarington, died December 18, 2004, at Wetzel County Hospital. She was born May 1, 1909, in Clarington, the daughter of the late Sanford and Ella Yaussey Fraley.
She lived a full and wonderfully useful life. She was a graduate of Hannibal High School, attended Oakwood Institute in Cincinnati, studying church music, she has been a life long member of Zion United Church of Christ, Sardis, where she served as the organist for 80 years and held various leadership positions, member of the Zion Women's Guild, and the Zion Grange # 2242. Music was a major part of her life; she was a piano teacher, a news correspondent for local papers for 75 years, a 4-H advisor, an accomplished quilter, caregiver and community strengthener. She loved her family and Zion Hilltop Community where she was active until the day of her death, and lived in her faith on a daily basis.
Surviving are her husband of 67 years, Walter F. Marty; three daughters, Lois Marty, at home, Sara (Marvin) Jacobs of Clarington, Eileen (Tom) Mignerey, of Pensacola, Florida; son Marvin (Heidi) Marty, of Albany; three grandsons, Devon (Jane) Jacobs of Albany, Todd (Kristy) Mignerey, of Flint, Michigan, Andy (Robin) Mignerey, of Jacksonville, Florida, ; two step-grandchildren, Madelyn and Ramsey Isaacs; three great-grandchildren, Logan, Kendall and Ryan Mignerey.
In addition to her parents, she was preceded in death by three sisters, Etta Dactwyler Roth, Mabel Krauter and Selma Krauter.
Friends were received December 21 at Grisell Funeral Home, Clarington, with Grange Services in the evening. Friends will also be received December 22 from noon until time of service at 1 p.m. at Zion United Church of Christ, Sardis. Burial in Mount Vernon Cemetery, Clarington.
Memorial contributions may be sent to Zion Church of Christ, 50445 State Route 536, Sardis, Ohio, for the stained glass window repair fund and for future landscaping projects. Sympathy expressions to www.grisellfuneralhomes.com

Marty, Robert W.

Source: Monroe County death records.
 

April 10, 1987

ANNIVERSARY

Marty, Walter and Lillian Fraley Marty

Source: Spirit of Democracy

     Walter and Lillian Marty will ======= JA'> Walter and Lillian Marty will >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 celebrate their golden wedding anniversary on April 26 with an open house at the Hilltop Community Center on Route 536 from 2 to 4 p.m. Mr. and Mrs. Marty were married on March 28, 1937 at the bride's home. Mr. Marty is the son of Alma Marty and the late J.W. Marty; Mrs. Marty is the daughter of the late Sanford and Ella Fraley. The couple has four children and three grandchildren. All their family and friends are invited to share this celebration with them.

     The Marty's request that their ======= JA'> The Marty's request that their >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 friends bring written memories of times they have shared with Walter and Lillian, to be placed in a friendship book, as the only gifts.

Mason, Bradley and Debra Cain
             Bradley Lee Mason and Debra Joan Cain were ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Bradley Lee Mason and Debra Joan Cain were >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 united in marriage June 11, 1978, at 2:30 p.m. in the South Main Street Church of Christ, Bethesda. Bradley is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Mason of 303 Second Street, Bethesda and Debra is the daughter of Mr. Glenn Cain, Route 1, Belmont and the late Mrs. Wanda Cain. Robert Jones officiated the double ring ceremony before a host of relatives and friends.
   Given in ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Given in >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 marriage by her father, the bride wore a full-length gown fashioned of white maracaine jersey with re-embroidered Alencon lace on the V-neckline, empire bodice, cap sleeves and wide border of Alencon lace Along the hem of the A-line silhouette skirt. White chiffon overlay on the skirt created a ruffled redingote look culminating in a chapel length train. A chiffon flower accented the cummerbund waistline. A chiffon fingertip veil edged in seed pearls was fashioned by the bride. She wore a cross necklace, gift of the groom and heirloom bracelet, which belonged to the groom's late grandmother, Nellie Cowgill. The bride's bouquet was of yellow roses, blue and yellow daisies, blue carnations and baby's breath.
   Maid of honor ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Maid of honor >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 was Marcia Haught, friend of the bride. Bridesmaids were Beverly Cain, Sheryl Cain, sisters of the bride, Nila Cain cousin of the bride, Cathy McCormick and Cathy Perkins. Their floor length gowns were made of qiana knit, bodice yoke trimmed in white lace with keyhole neckline and tie belt in back. The maid of honor wore pastel yellow and the bridesmaids were dressed in pastel blue. Each carried a white basket of yellow and blue daisies, blue carnations and baby's breath. Their hair was adorned with a sprig of baby's breath.
   Serving as ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Serving as >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 best man was John McCormick friend of the groom. Ushers were Bryan Mason, brother of the groom, Neil Hunt, Douglas Kemp, friends of the groom, Larry Cain and Bradley Cain, the bride's brothers. The best man and the fathers wore yellow tuxedos, and the ushers wore blue tuxedos.
   Mrs. Mason ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Mrs. Mason >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 wore for her son's wedding a yellow qiana knit A-line gown and blue and yellow flowered chiffon jacket, and matching gloves. She wore a corsage of yellow roses and blue carnations and daisies.
   Soloist was ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Soloist was >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Cathy McCormick and Cindy McCann accompanying at the piano. Selections were "More", "You Light Up My Life", "Bridge Over Troubled Waters" and "The Wedding Song", which was sung during the marriage ceremony. Other piano music included was "Color My World', and 'Evergreen".
   Attending the ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Attending the >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 guest book was Judy Morrison. Rice girls were Lori Bundy, cousins of the bride and Gina Agostic, cousin of the groom. The reception was held at the Epworth Park Lodge hosted by Connie Cain, Freda Mueller, Januaryice Bundy, Judy Cain, Kay Watson, and Linda Christman, all aunts of the bride. A three tiered heart shaped cake, adorned with confectioner's daisies was topped with satin bells. The cake was made by the groom's cousin, Patty Henderson.
   The new Mr. ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> The new Mr. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 and Mrs. Mason spent a brief honeymoon at Niagara Falls, Canada before making their home at 313 First Street, Bethesda, Ohio.

Mason, Mary (nee Franklin)
            Mary W. Mason, aged 30 years, 3 ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Mary W. Mason, aged 30 years, 3 >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 months, and 28 days, died near Woodsfield December 3, 1862. She was born August 5, 1832, the daughter of Alexander and Mary Franklin of Noble County, Ohio and among the first settlers in this part of the country. Mary was their fourth daughter. Mary and Henry R. Mason were married October 25, 1855, by the Reverend James McGinnis. She leaves 3 small children. Source: The Spirit of Democracy, January 28, 1863.
 
Mason, Thomas L., Jr.

======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Wheeling, West Virginia >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
Published-January 30, 2000
Mason, Thomas L.  ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'>Mason, Thomas L. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Jr., 72, of New Martinsville, West Virginia., died Saturday, January 29, 2000, in Wheeling Hospital. He was retired from Ormet Corporation, Hannibal, Ohio, a veteran of the Korean War and a member of Saint Johns United Methodist Church, New Martinsville. He was preceded in death by his parents, Thomas L. and Ora Pyles Mason; a brother, Hubert; and three sisters, Lucille Gilbert, Beulah Yeater and Kathleen Morris. Surviving are his wife, Joanne Sidell Mason; two sons, Mark of Paden City and Brent of New Martinsville; a brother, Fred of Parkersburg; a sister, Flossie Kourey of Charleston; and three grandchildren. Friends received 4-9 p.m. Sunday at Iams Funeral Home, 833 Third Street, New Martinsville, where services will be held at 1 p.m. Monday. Interment in Greenlawn Memorial Park, New Martinsville. Masonic graveside services by Wetzel Lodge Number 39 A.F.& A.M. Memorial contributions may be made to American Legion Post 28, New Martinsville, West Virginia. [Wheeling News-Register, Wheeling, West Virginia., 30 January 2000]

Masters, Frank
            Frank Masters, son of Charles Masters ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Frank Masters, son of Charles Masters >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 of Greenbrier, met by drowning in the Arkansas River in Oklahoma Sunday. His brother Denver left at once for that place and brought the remains to the home at Greenbrier, Saturday. The funeral was held Sunday afternoon at two o'clock. The young man was a cousin of Jas. Masters of this place. His brother Everett who was to go Monday morning with Monroe County's quota to Camp Sherman was excused from reporting to the local board for 48 hours. Source: The Spirit of Democracy, Thursday, June 27, 1918.

Masters, Richard S. and Shirley Smith
Source--Monroe County Beacon     Woodsfield, Ohio
======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Woodsfield, Ohio >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
Published--December 6, 1954
 Smith, Miss ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Smith, Miss >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Shirley, daughter of Stella Smith of Woodsfield, became the bride of Mr. Richard S. Masters, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sam Masters, also of Woodsfield, on Sunday, November fourteenth, in the Presbyterian Church at Woodsfield.. The double ring ceremony was read by Reverend L. Lane McCammon at three o'clock in the afternoon.
                                Tall white baskets of white ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Tall white baskets of white >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 chrysanthemums and seven-branch candelbra formed the setting for the ceremony.
                                During the ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> During the >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 seating of the guests, Mrs. Charles Sinclair presented a selection of appropriate wedding numbers on the organ and played the traditional wedding marches.
                                Given in ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Given in >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 marriage by her uncle, Walter Christman, of Woodsfield, the bride was lovely in a floor-length wedding gown of Chantilly lace and nylon tulle over satin. It was fashioned with a bolero jacket of lace which buttoned in front, had a Peter Pan collar and long lace sleeves coming to points over the hands. From the formal bodice of nylon tulle fell a very bouffant tulle skirt enhanced with a shorter tulle overskirt trimmed with a wide panel of lace and worn over net and satin and an old-fashioned hoop skirt. Her fingertip veil of imported silk illusion was caught by a half hat of lace trimmed with seed pearls. She carried a white Bible topped with a white orchid.
 
                                Miss Anna Laura ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Miss Anna Laura >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Hall, as maid of honor, wore a ballerina length gown of American Beauty orlon taffeta, with a matching headband. The gown was made with a strpless molded bodice with a full skirt covered with narrow ruffles. She carried white chrysanthemums in a cascade arrangement and tied with ribbon to match her gown.
 
                                Gerald ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Gerald >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Hamilton, of Marietta was best man. Ushers were Merle Berry and Nile Kamp, of Woodsfield, and William Dougherty, of Wellsburg, West Virginia.
 
                                A reception was ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> A reception was >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 held in the church parlors where the bride's mother received her guests in a blue taffeta dress and matching jacket, with black accessories. The groom's mother wore a red wool dress and jacket, with black accessories. Both wore a gardenia corsage.
 
                                After a wedding trip to Ocala and West Palm Beach, Florida.  ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> After a wedding trip to Ocala and West Palm Beach, Florida. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Mr. Masters and this bride are now residing with his parents. They will move into their newly built home at 102 Oaklawn Avenue for the Christmas holidays.
 
                                Mrs. Masters ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Mrs. Masters >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 was graduated from the Graysville High School and is employed in the office of the Aid For The Aged.
 
                                Mr. Masters was ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Mr. Masters was >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 graduated from Woodsfield High School, attended Ohio State University and served in the United States Armed Forces. He is now associated with his father in Masters Transfer.

Matesick, Nick                                                                                                          Source--Times Leader      Martins Ferry, Ohio                                                                       ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Died: April 7, 1925. Source: Monroe County death records.
Matesick, Nick Source--Times Leader Martins Ferry, Ohio >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Published---September 21, 2004
 
Matesick, Nicholas "Butch" , 75, of Powhatan Point, Ohio died Sunday, September 19, 2004 at the Wheeling Hospital in Wheeling, West Virginia. He was born November 6, 1928 in Powhatan Point, Ohio a son of the late Nicholas and Helen Markovich Matesick.Nick was a retired foreman for the North American Coal Company's Number 1 and 6 Mines at Powhatan Point, Ohio and a member of the Powhatan United Methodist Church in Powhatan Point, Ohio. Nick loved his tomato patch, homemade sauce and his well-know home-made wine. He was preceded in death by one brother, John Matesick in 1945. Surviving are his wife of 54 years, Mildred "Midge" Crozier Matesick one son, Terry Matesick and his wife, Tracey of Powhatan Point, Ohio, two daughters, Marsha Baker and her husband, Gary of Powhatan Point, Ohio and Rosie Matesick of St. Clairsville, Ohio, three sisters, Ann Korner and Helen "Cookie" Kriechbaum both of Powhatan Point, Ohio and Barb Mitchell of Lansing, Ohio, one brother, Milan "Mil" Matesick of Powhatan Point, Ohio; four grandchildren and three great grandchildren. Family and friends will be received at the Bauknecht-Altmeyer Funeral Homes & Crematory, 186 Main St. Powhatan Point, Ohio on Tuesday from 2 to 4 and 6 to 8 p.m. where services will be held on Wednesday at 11 a.m. with the Rev. Richard Hendrix officiating. Interment in the Powhatan Cemetery at Powhatan Point, Ohio. Memorial contributions may be made to the Powhatan Emergency Squad, 104 Mellott Street, Powhatan Point, Ohio 43942. Online condolences can be made to Nick's family at www.altmeyer.com

Mathews, Mary Elizabeth Zink
Source--Moundsville Echo    Moundsville, West Virginia
======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Moundsville, West Virginia >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
Published--Wednesday, February 5, 1917
 
Mathews, William D.
 
Double Service Saturday: Mr. and Mrs. Mathews
 
  Cameron, West Virginia, February 5 (Spl) - Double funeral services will be held in the First Christian Church Saturday afternoon at 2:30 oclock for Mr. and Mrs. William D. ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Cameron, West Virginia, February 5 (Spl) - Double funeral services will be held in the First Christian Church Saturday afternoon at 2:30 o clock for Mr. and Mrs. William D. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Mathews who succumbed from the effects of pneumonia within two days of each other. Mary Elizabeth Zink Mathews died Sunday afternoon, and William D. Mathews, 79, passed away at 8:45 a.m., this morning. Both had been ill only a few days. Reverend W. E. Pierce, of the Christian church will officiate.
  Mr. Mathews ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Mr. Mathews >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 was a well-known retired business man of Cameron. He was born at Big Run, in Marshall county, and had spent his entire life in this district. He had been engaged at various times in the tailoring business and as an operator of a greenhouse. Some five years ago, he retired from active business life. The deceased was a member of the First Christian church, serving on its board of trustees. Surviving are one sister, Mrs. Gilmore Rine, Moundsville; and three brothers, James Mathews of Malaga, Ohio; J. H. Mathews of Carrolton, Ohio, and Hughie Mathews of Big Run. Interment will be made in Big Run cemetery.

Mathews, William
Source: Moundsville Echo,           Moundsville, West Virginia
======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Moundsville, West Virginia >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
Published--September 4, 1917
 
IN MEMORIAM
Mathews, William , the youngest and last surviving son of John and Susie Pluessinger Mathews, was born April 13, 1825 and departed this life August 15, 1917 being 92 years four months and two days of age.
He was born in Washington County, Pennsylvania, and when but a child his parents moved to what is now Bellton, West Virginia. After residing there for a few years the family moved to Big Run. Here he resided until death came, his last earthly home being with his son, M. B. Mathews. He was a life long member of the Christian church, his father being in his later years a minister of that faith.
William Mathews and Susan Sampson were united in marriage November. 8, 1845.
To this union twelve children were born. Emma K. Mathews, Mary A. Charnock, John W. Mathews and Susan Jane Mathews had already preceded him to the better land. The latter was the first buried in the present Big Run cemetery.
Besides the aged wife who is now past 90 years of age, he leaves the following children: George A., S. Huey, William D., and Mayes B. Mathews all of Cameron; Mrs. Gilmore Rine of Rosby Rock, Mrs. Irwin Manning of Cameron, James of Malaga, Ohio, and Jacob A. Mathews of Hopedale, Ohio. Also 51 grandchildren.
His body was conveyed to its last resting place by his grandsons, Luther Mathews, R. E. Mathews of Hopedale, Roy and Bell Manning of Cameron, and W. G. Rine of Moundsville.
 
Call not back the dear departed,
Anchored safe where storms are oer
======= mso-fareast-language:JA'>Anchored safe where storms are o er >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
We shall find our missing loved one
In our Fathers mansion fair.

Matson, Francis O. Jack, Jr.
            (August ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'>Matson, Francis O. Jack , Jr.
(August >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 10, 1943 - March 28, 2002)
A funeral service for Francis O. "Jack" Matson, Jr., 58, of Buckeye Lake, will be held at 7p.m. today at Criss-Schoedinger Funeral Chapel with pastor Bob Perdue officiating. Burial will follow at a later date in Newark Memorial Gardens.
            Mr. ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Mr. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Matson died March 28, 2002, at Selma Markowitz Hospice Care Center. He was born August 10, 1943, in Troy, to the late Francis O. Matson Sr. and Mary Elizabeth (Wilson) Hosmer.
            Mr. ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Mr. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Matson worked at Diebold, Incorporated For 28 years. He served in the Navy in the 1960's, and was a member of the CWA-AFL-CIO local #84710.
            Mr. ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Mr. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Matson is survived by his wife of 28 years, Betty I. Matthews, Charles F.
NEW MATAMORAS - Charles F. Mathews, 91, of 35166 State Route 26, New Matamoras, formerly of Lewisville, Ohio, died at 5:27 a.m. Wednesday (March 3, 2004) at Barnesville Hospital in Barnesville.
He was born May 30, 1912, near Antioch to Calob and Annie Mae Brown Mathews. He was a retired lineman and truck driver for the Hoosier Construction Co. and was a member of the Church of Christ.
 
He is survived by four sons, Paul Mathews of Dalton, Ohio, Ed Mathews and Dean Mathews, both of Woodsfield, and Roger Mathews of Glencoe, Ohio; two brothers, Howard Mathews and Virgil Mathews, both of Mount Pleasant, Ohio; 10 grandchildren; several great-grandchildren; and a special partner in life, Barbara Randolph of New Matamoras.
 
He was preceded in death by his wife, Edna Shook Mathews, on Jan. 21, 1990; his parents; three brothers, Roy, Alva and Curtis Mathews; and four sisters, Nellie Sims, Carrie McCormick, Vernie Shook and Laura Connally.
 
Services are at 1 p.m. Friday at Watters Funeral Home, 37501 State Route 78 West, Woodsfield, with Harold Kinney Jr. officiating. Burial is in Friendship Cemetery in Lewisville. Friends will be received from 11 a.m. to 1 p.m. Friday at the funeral home.
 
 
Mattone, Dorothy M., nee Doty
Source--Monroe County Beacon   Woodsfield, Ohio
======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Woodsfield, Ohio >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
Published--Thursday, October 1, 1998
            Dorothy ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Dorothy >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Madeline Mattone, 83, of 53437 Township Highway # 2788 Clarington, died September 27, 1998, in Wheeling Hospital, Wheeling.
She was born December 19, 1914 at Pipe Creek, a daughter of the late Archibald and Jenny Bellville Doty.
She was a member of Saint John Vianney Catholic Church, Powhatan Point.
Surviving are her husband, John G. Mattone; four daughters, Margaret Speece, Clarington, Juanita Cordery and Virginia Elerick, both of Brunswick, Sandra Baumberger, of Beallsville; seven grandchildren; seven great-grandchildren.
She was preceded in death by a son John Wayne Mattone; one grandson, Andy Speece; four brothers ; four sisters.
Friends were received at the Rush Funeral Home, Clarington, September 29. Private funeral services with Liturgy was held September 30 at the convenience of the family in Saint John Vianney Catholic Church, Powhatan Point. Burial followed in Powhatan Cemetery, Powhatan Point.

Matz, Christian Adam
            Christian ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Christian >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Adam Matz was born on March 27, 1864 near Woodsfield, Ohio in Monroe County. Christian and Lou Ellen Latta , were married on July 16, 1901 in Monroe County, Ohio by Reverend Thes. A. Hofell. Lou Ellen was born on March 31, 1871, the daughter of John and Mary J. Morris Latta. Christian was a carpenter by trade. Christian, Lou Ellen and five children lived in Lewisville, Ohio until about 1916 when they moved to Ashland, Ohio. Christian, age 83, passed away Saturday morning, October 12, 1946, at his home in Ashland. He suffered a stroke for two months and then followed by another stroke. Funeral services were held on Monday afternoon in at the Gilbert funeral home in Ashland with Reverenc H.H. <<<<<<< HEAD Lentz in charge. Burial was in Ashland cemetery. Matz, Clyde J. <<<<<<< HEAD Shorty
               Clyde ======= Shorty
Clyde >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 J. (Shorty) Matz, 56, of 500 Middle Street, Polk, Ohio, died January 31, 1993, at his residence after a lingering illness. He was born on September 7, 1936, in Lewisville, Monroe County, Ohio to the late Willie T. and Nellie L. Morris Matz. He moved to Ashland, Ohio from Monroe County and had been an area resident for the past 38 years. He was retired from Eagle Rubber as a group leader in 1984, after 29 years service. He was affiliated with the Paradise Hill United Methodist Church. He was also a member of the Polk Volunteer Fire Department and had been active in the community with several youth programs.
               He ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> He >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 is survived by his wife, Florence JoAnn Miller, whom he married October 14, 1955; three sons, Rocky L. and Ronald L., both Ashland and Ray W. of Mansfield; two sisters, Mrs. Paul (Norma Lee) Wilson and Bertha Cranmore, both of Ashland; one brother, Walter S. of Zanesville; six grandchildren.

Burial followed in the Ashland Cemetery.
Source: The Monroe County Beacon, Thursday, February 4, 1993.

Matz, Jennifer Ann

Matz, Johannes Jacob
            Fifth ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> Fifth >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 child of Jacob and Louise Walther Matz: Johannes Jacob Matz
Johannes Jacob Matz was born March 5, 1829 in <<<<<<< HEAD Oberschlettenbach, Germany  and was baptized in Vorderweidenthal, Germany on March 8, 1829. Jacob  married Elizabeth Meckling. She was born ======= Oberschlettenbach, Germany and was baptized in Vorderweidenthal, Germany on March 8, 1829. Jacob married Elizabeth Meckling. She was born >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 October 19, 1877 and died June 17, 1912. Jacob died in Adams Township, Monroe Csounty, Ohio, Sunday, September 11, 1887 at the age of 58 years, 6 months and 6 days. Jacob was a veteran and a farmer. He is buried in the Pioneer Cemetery.
            In Memorian published in the Tuesday, September 20, 1887, Spirit  of Democracy, Woodsfield, Ohio - Whereas, It ======= mso-fareast-language:JA'> In Memorian published in the Tuesday, September 20, 1887, Spirit of Democracy, Woodsfield, Ohio - Whereas, It >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 has pleased an allwise Providence to remove from our ranks, by the had of death, our worthy comrade, Jacob Matz, to join that Grand Army whose roll-call grows larger each year; therefore, resolved, that in the death of Jacob Matz, General William P. Richardson, Post Number 609 has lost one of its most worthy comrades, his widow of kind and loving husband, the community an honest and honorable citizen and his country one of its brave defenders. Resolved, that we deeply deplore the loss of our comrade, and extend to his widow and friend our heartfelt sympathy. Resolved, that a copy of this memorial be spread upon the minutes of the Post, sent to the widow of our deceased comrade and published in the County papers., written by Captain William Dougherty, Louis Sulsberger, and A. T. Pearson, committee.

He had been a resident of Ashland for 59 years coming here from Louisville. (Lewisville)

Other survivors include one son, David B. of Ashland and two sisters, Marguerite Matz of Ashland and Mrs. John O'Neil of Marion, Indiana.
    He was preceded in death by his parents and ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> He was preceded in death by his parents and >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 two sisters.
    He was a member of Masonic Ashland Blue ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> He was a member of Masonic Ashland Blue >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Lodge Number 151 F&AM, Chapter Number 67 and Council No. 128. He was also a member of First United Methodist Church.
    Funeral service will be held at 1:30 p.m. ======= style='mso-spacerun:yes'> Funeral service will be held at 1:30 p.m. >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711 Monday at Gilbert Funeral Home with Reverend Merlin Vining officiating. Burial will be in Ashland Cemetery.

               Granted License
======= style='mso-tab-count:1'> Granted License >>>>>>> ef9da23e9f6816b69f175e37096e452723be7711
Leland Matz, well known here, was granted a second class steam engineer's license, following an examination held recently in Zanesville. Leland is the son of Mr. and Mrs. W. F. Matz, North Main street, and is employed as an engineer at Nestle Milk Products plant, Greenville.
